title: William Forster (judge)
text:
Sir William Edward Stanley Forster (15 June 1921 – 31 January 1997) was the first <a href="Chief%20Justice%20of%20the%20Northern%20Territory">Chief Justice</a> of the <a href="Supreme%20Court%20of%20the%20Northern%20Territory">Supreme Court of the Northern Territory</a> holding that position from 1979 to 1985. Before that he was the first (and only) <a href="Chief%20Justice%20of%20the%20Northern%20Territory%23List%20of%20Chief%20Judges%20of%20the%20Northern%20Territory">Chief Judge</a> from 1977 to 1979 and <a href="Chief%20Justice%20of%20the%20Northern%20Territory%23List%20of%20Chief%20Judges%20of%20the%20Northern%20Territory">Senior Judge</a> from 1971 to 1977, all positions which were effectively the same.
Sir William was born in <a href="Sydney%2C%20New%20South%20Wales">Sydney, New South Wales</a> on 15 June 1921 and, after moving to <a href="Adelaide">Adelaide</a> in 1929, attended <a href="St%20Peter%27s%20College%2C%20Adelaide">St Peter's College, Adelaide</a>.
Early legal life.
Forster graduated with a <a href="Bachelor%20of%20Laws">Bachelor of Laws</a> from the <a href="University%20of%20Adelaide">University of Adelaide</a>. He was in the <a href="Royal%20Australian%20Air%20Force">Royal Australian Air Force</a> from 1940 to 1946 and was a <a href="Magistrate">Magistrate</a> at the <a href="Adelaide%20Police%20Court">Adelaide Police Court</a> from 1959 to 1961. He was <a href="District%20Registrar">District Registrar</a> of the <a href="High%20Court%20of%20Australia">High Court of Australia</a> from 1966 to 1971 and before that was <a href="District%20Registrar">District Registrar</a> from 1961 to 1966; and was Master of the <a href="Supreme%20Court%20of%20South%20Australia">Supreme Court of South Australia</a> from 1966 to 1971 and <a href="Deputy%20Master">Deputy Master</a> from 1961 to 1966.
A member of the <a href="Standing%20Committee%20Senate">Standing Committee Senate</a> at the <a href="Adelaide%20University">Adelaide University</a> from 1967 to 1971, Forster was lecturer of <a href="Law%20and%20Procedure">Law and Procedure</a> at the same time and lecturer of <a href="Criminal%20Law">Criminal Law</a> from 1957 to 1958.
As Judge of the Northern Territory Supreme Court.
He was appointed <a href="Senior%20Judge">Senior Judge</a> of the <a href="Supreme%20Court%20of%20the%20Northern%20Territory">Supreme Court of the Northern Territory</a> on 28 June 1971 and replaced <a href="Justice%20Blackburn">Justice Blackburn</a> who had taken up appointment with the <a href="Supreme%20Court%20of%20the%20Australian%20Capital%20Territory">Supreme Court of the Australian Capital Territory</a>.
After <a href="Cyclone%20Tracy">Cyclone Tracy</a> had destroyed <a href="Darwin%2C%20Northern%20Territory">Darwin</a> in 1974, Justice Forster ensured the <a href="Supreme%20court">Supreme Court</a> was fully functional by March 1975.
Chief Justice Forster was a Member of the <a href="Aboriginal%20Theatre%20Foundation">Aboriginal Theatre Foundation</a> from 1972 to 1975 and President of the Northern Territory Division of the <a href="Australian%20Red%20Cross">Australian Red Cross</a> from 1973 to 1985. He was also <a href="Chairman">Chairman</a> of the <a href="Museum%20and%20Galleries%20Board%20of%20the%20Northern%20Territory">Museum and Galleries Board of the Northern Territory</a> from 1974 to 1985.
Chief Justice Forster was Chairman of the <a href="Northern%20Territory%20Parole%20Board">Northern Territory Parole Board</a> from 1976 to 1985 and held a Dormant Commission as <a href="Administrator%20of%20the%20Northern%20Territory">Acting Administrator</a> of the Northern Territory from 1976 to 1985. He was also a Justice of the <a href="Federal%20Court%20of%20Australia">Federal Court of Australia</a> from 1977 to 1989.
Chief Justice Forster was a champion of the local legal profession and upon his retirement expressed a wish that vacancies on the Bench be filled by local practitioners. Indeed, all appointments to the Supreme Court from 1991 (other than that of Chief Justice <a href="Brian%20Ross%20Martin">Brian Ross Martin</a> in 2004) have been from the local profession. 
In 1976, Chief Justice Forster was responsible for the introduction of the '<a href="Anunga%20Rules">Anunga Rules</a>' which, established guidelines for the interrogation of Aboriginal and non-English-speaking persons by Police to ensure that admissions were voluntarily obtained.
He retired in 1985 due to ill-health and relocated to <a href="Perth%2C%20Western%20Australia">Perth</a>.
Awards and honours.
Justice Forster was awarded a <a href="Knight%20Bachelor">Knight Bachelor</a> in 1982 for services to law and is the only person to be <a href="knight">knight</a>ed for services to the <a href="Northern%20Territory">Northern Territory</a>.
<a href="William%20Forster%20Chambers">William Forster Chambers</a> in Darwin now carries his name.
